title: Cervical Spondylotic Myelopathy (Degenerative Cervical Myelopathy)
scope: ** Evaluation and management of chronic/progressive spinal cord dysfunction from degenerative cervical spine changes (disc herniation, osteophyte formation, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, ossification of the posterior longitudinal ligament). Covers diagnostic workup, severity grading (mJOA), surgical referral criteria, conservative management of mild cases, symptomatic treatment (spasticity, pain, bladder dysfunction), and post-surgical monitoring. Excludes acute traumatic spinal cord injury, acute myelopathy from non-degenerative causes (inflammatory, infectious, vascular — see Acute Myelopathy template), isolated cervical radiculopathy without myelopathy, and cauda equina syndrome (separate template).

Essential/First-line.item: MRI cervical spine without and with gadolinium contrast (CPT 72156)
Essential/First-line.timing: STAT if acute neurologic deterioration; URGENT for new/progressive myelopathic symptoms; ROUTINE for outpatient evaluation
Essential/First-line.target: Cord compression (disc, osteophyte, ligamentum flavum hypertrophy, OPLL); T2 hyperintensity within cord (myelomalacia or edema); T1 hypointensity (irreversible cord damage — poor prognostic sign); canal stenosis measurement
Essential/First-line.contraindications: GFR <30 (relative — give contrast if needed); gadolinium allergy (premedicate); pacemaker/implant (MRI-conditional protocol)

Essential/First-line.item: X-ray cervical spine AP, lateral, and flexion-extension views (CPT 72052)

Referrals & Consults.item: Neurology consult for diagnosis confirmation, myelopathy severity grading (mJOA score), and differentiation from non-spondylotic myelopathy
Spine surgery (neurosurgery or orthopedic spine) for surgical candidacy evaluation in moderate-severe myelopathy (mJOA <15) or progressive deficit
Physical therapy for gait training, balance assessment, fall prevention, strengthening of upper and lower extremities, and cervical stabilization exercises
Occupational therapy for fine motor assessment, hand dexterity rehabilitation (myelopathy hand), ADL adaptation, assistive device fitting, and home safety evaluation

Pain management referral for refractory neuropathic pain not responding to first-line and second-line agents, or for consideration of interventional procedures (cervical epidural steroid injection, nerve blocks)
Rehabilitation medicine (physiatry) for comprehensive functional assessment, rehabilitation program coordination, and disposition planning
Urology for neurogenic bladder evaluation, urodynamic testing, and management of urinary retention or incontinence
Speech-language pathology for swallow evaluation if dysphagia symptoms present (cervical cord compression may affect bulbar function; also assess post-operatively after anterior cervical surgery)
Respiratory therapy for pulmonary function assessment if high cervical cord compression (C3-C5) affecting diaphragmatic function
Social work for discharge planning, durable medical equipment coordination, disability assessment, and caregiver support
Psychology or psychiatry for adjustment disorder, depression, and anxiety related to chronic disability and functional limitation

Patient Instructions.item: Return to ED immediately if sudden worsening of weakness, new inability to walk, loss of bowel or bladder control, or difficulty breathing (may indicate acute cord compression requiring emergency surgery)
Avoid high-risk activities including contact sports, diving, trampolines, roller coasters, and extreme neck flexion/extension (risk of acute cord injury with narrowed spinal canal)
Use caution on stairs and uneven surfaces; use handrails at all times due to impaired balance and gait instability from myelopathy
Do not drive until cleared by neurology or spine surgeon due to impaired hand dexterity, delayed reaction time, and balance impairment
Perform prescribed physical therapy and occupational therapy exercises between sessions to maintain and improve function

Report any new numbness in hands, increasing hand clumsiness (dropping objects, difficulty with buttons), or worsening gait to your neurologist promptly as these may indicate disease progression requiring surgical intervention
If wearing cervical collar, follow prescribed schedule; perform skin checks under collar daily to prevent pressure sores
After cervical spine surgery: follow all post-operative activity restrictions; report fever, wound drainage, increasing pain, new weakness, or difficulty swallowing immediately
Keep follow-up appointments with spine surgeon and neurologist; repeat MRI will be needed to monitor response to treatment

Lifestyle & Prevention.item: Smoking cessation to improve surgical outcomes and reduce pseudarthrosis risk (smoking impairs bone fusion by up to 2-3 fold)
Fall prevention: remove loose rugs, install grab bars in bathroom, use non-slip mats, adequate lighting, and wear supportive footwear with non-slip soles
Ergonomic workstation setup: monitor at eye level, avoid prolonged neck flexion (looking down at phone/laptop), use document holders, take breaks every 30 minutes
Weight management to reduce axial loading on cervical spine and optimize surgical outcomes (BMI >35 associated with worse outcomes)
Low-impact exercise program (swimming, stationary cycling, walking) to maintain cardiovascular fitness and muscle strength without high-impact cervical loading
Cervical spine protection: avoid extreme neck flexion/extension; use appropriate cervical pillow for sleep; avoid overhead work for prolonged periods
Bone health optimization: calcium 1000-1200 mg/day + vitamin D 1000-2000 IU/day for patients with osteoporosis risk to improve fusion outcomes
Bowel program maintenance with adequate fiber (25-30 g/day), fluid intake (2L/day), and regular toileting schedule to prevent neurogenic bowel complications
Depression and anxiety screening at each follow-up visit using PHQ-9 and GAD-7; chronic myelopathy carries high rates of mood disorders
Alcohol moderation to reduce fall risk and avoid interaction with medications (gabapentin, pregabalin, muscle relaxants)

differential.tests: MRI cervical spine (syrinx cavity within cord); MRI brain/cervicomedullary junction (Chiari); CSF flow study

differential.features: Gait apraxia (magnetic gait); urinary incontinence; cognitive decline (triad); shuffling rather than spastic gait
differential.tests: MRI brain (ventriculomegaly out of proportion to atrophy); lumbar puncture with large-volume tap test (gait improvement)

differential.features: Mimics B12 deficiency; posterior column + corticospinal tract; history of gastric surgery, zinc supplements, or chronic zinc exposure
differential.tests: Serum copper and ceruloplasmin (low); zinc level (may be elevated); MRI (posterior column T2 signal)

differential.features: Progressive spastic paraparesis; endemic areas (Caribbean, Japan, sub-Saharan Africa); bladder dysfunction prominent; slow progression over years
differential.tests: HTLV-1 antibody (serum and CSF); MRI may show cord atrophy without structural compression

differential.features: Older male; progressive myelopathy; flow voids on MRI; dorsal cord edema disproportionate to enhancement; stepwise or progressive course
differential.tests: MRI (flow voids, dorsal cord edema); spinal angiography (gold standard); presentation overlaps with CSM in older patients

differential.features: Family history; slowly progressive bilateral lower extremity spasticity; onset often younger; minimal sensory findings; normal MRI structurally
differential.tests: Genetic testing (SPG genes); family history; MRI spine (cord atrophy without compression); EMG/NCS

differential.features: Hyperacute onset (minutes to hours); anterior spinal artery syndrome (motor + pain/temperature loss, preserved proprioception); vascular risk factors
differential.tests: MRI DWI (restricted diffusion); CTA aorta; vascular risk factors; onset is acute (vs CSM which is chronic/progressive)

differential.features: Overlaps with CSM; more common in East Asian populations; may be incidental on imaging; progressive myelopathy from ossified ligament
differential.tests: CT cervical spine (ossified ligament — better seen than MRI); MRI for cord compression and signal change; distinguished by mechanism but managed similarly to CSM

differential.features: Non-anatomic sensory loss; Hoover sign; give-way weakness; inconsistent exam findings; normal MRI
differential.tests: Normal MRI spine; normal electrodiagnostic studies; positive signs on exam (Hoover, drift without pronation)

evidence.recommendation: Surgical decompression superior to conservative management for moderate-severe CSM
evidence.source: [Fehlings et al. CSM-North America (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/24499474/); [Fehlings et al. Spine (2017)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/28291407/)

evidence.recommendation: Earlier surgical intervention associated with better neurologic outcomes in moderate-severe CSM
evidence.source: [Tetreault et al. Neurosurgery (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26378358/); duration of symptoms is strongest predictor of outcome

evidence.recommendation: mJOA score validated for severity grading and surgical decision-making in CSM
evidence.source: [Tetreault et al. Global Spine J (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/26682095/); mild ≥15, moderate 12-14, severe <12

evidence.recommendation: MRI T2 signal change (myelomalacia) correlates with worse surgical outcomes
evidence.source: [Nouri et al. Spine (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25893357/); [Tetreault et al. Spine (2013)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23962996/)

evidence.recommendation: T1 hypointensity on MRI indicates irreversible cord damage and poorer prognosis
ACDF effective for 1-2 level anterior compression in CSM
Laminoplasty effective for multi-level posterior compression with preserved lordosis
evidence.source: [Hirabayashi et al. Spine (1983)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/6420895/); original technique; multiple validation studies

evidence.recommendation: C5 palsy occurs in 5-10% after posterior decompression; usually recovers
evidence.source: [Nassr et al. J Bone Joint Surg Am (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22293780/)

evidence.recommendation: Conservative management reasonable for mild CSM (mJOA ≥15) with close monitoring
evidence.source: [Kadanka et al. Spine (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/21519928/); mild cases may not progress; surgery for progression

evidence.recommendation: Smoking cessation improves fusion rates and surgical outcomes
evidence.source: [Berman et al. Spine (2017)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29849372/); pseudarthrosis rates 2-3x higher in smokers

evidence.recommendation: Gabapentin and pregabalin effective for neuropathic pain in myelopathy
evidence.source: [Finnerup et al. Lancet Neurol (2015)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/25575710/); NeuPSIG guidelines for neuropathic pain

evidence.recommendation: Baclofen first-line for spasticity in spinal cord conditions
evidence.source: Expert consensus; extensive clinical experience; [Taricco et al. Cochrane (2000)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/10796750/)

evidence.recommendation: DVT prophylaxis in acute myelopathy with immobilization
evidence.source: High thrombotic risk in immobilized patients with spinal cord dysfunction; [Geerts et al. Chest (2008)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/18574271/)

evidence.recommendation: Retropharyngeal hematoma is life-threatening complication after anterior cervical surgery requiring emergent surgical evacuation
evidence.source: [Palumbo et al. Eur Spine J (2012)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/23477277/); incidence 1-6%; airway compromise can be fatal

evidence.recommendation: AAN/CNS/AANS guidelines recommend against conservative management for rapidly progressive CSM
Flexion-extension X-rays for dynamic instability assessment in CSM
evidence.source: Expert consensus; translation >3.5 mm or angulation >11° indicates instability requiring fusion

evidence.recommendation: Tandem stenosis (cervical + lumbar) present in 5-25% of CSM patients
evidence.source: [Dagi et al. J Neurosurg Spine (2011)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/22220162/); always evaluate for tandem stenosis

evidence.recommendation: OPLL more common in East Asian populations; CT superior to MRI for detection
evidence.source: [Epstein et al. Spine (2002)](https://pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/12435969/); prevalence 1.9-4.3% in Japanese populations

evidence.recommendation: Intermittent catheterization preferred over indwelling catheter for neurogenic bladder
evidence.source: Spinal cord injury guidelines; lower UTI rates with intermittent catheterization

monitoring.item: Neurologic exam (motor strength, sensory level, reflexes, gait assessment, hand dexterity — grip and release test)
monitoring.frequency: ED: at presentation; HOSP: q4-8h x 48h, then q shift; OPD: each visit; ICU: q2-4h
monitoring.action: If worsening motor exam or ascending sensory level: STAT MRI; urgent surgical consult

monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; at each outpatient visit; pre- and post-operatively
monitoring.action: mJOA <12 or declining score: urgent surgical referral; mJOA decline >1 point warrants re-evaluation

monitoring.item: Respiratory function (FVC, NIF) — if C3-C5 compression
monitoring.frequency: q4-6h if cervical cord compression above C5; q2h if declining
monitoring.action: FVC <20 mL/kg or NIF weaker than -30 cmH2O: ICU transfer; prepare for intubation

monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; daily inpatient; each outpatient visit initially
monitoring.action: PVR >200 mL: start intermittent catheterization; >500 mL: Foley catheter; urology referral

monitoring.item: Pain assessment (NRS 0-10; neuropathic pain screening — DN4 or LANSS)
monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; daily inpatient; each outpatient visit
monitoring.action: NRS >6 despite treatment: escalate analgesics; consider pain management referral; distinguish nociceptive vs neuropathic

monitoring.item: Gait assessment (Nurick grade; 10-meter walk test; Timed Up and Go)
monitoring.frequency: At initial evaluation; each outpatient visit; post-operatively at 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months
monitoring.action: Progressive gait deterioration: urgent surgical reassessment; PT intensification

monitoring.frequency: q1h x 6h post-op, then q2h x 18h
monitoring.action: Stridor or progressive neck swelling: EMERGENCY — retropharyngeal hematoma; STAT surgical evacuation; secure airway
New post-operative weakness (especially C5 palsy with deltoid/biceps weakness): STAT MRI to rule out epidural hematoma; dexamethasone; most C5 palsies recover over weeks-months

monitoring.frequency: Post-operative: before discharge, 6 weeks, 3 months, 6 months, 12 months, then annually
monitoring.action: Hardware failure, cage subsidence, pseudarthrosis: surgical revision consideration; adjacent segment disease: monitor closely, repeat MRI if symptomatic

monitoring.frequency: 3-6 months post-operative; then if new symptoms; annually for conservatively managed patients
monitoring.action: Persistent or new cord compression: surgical reassessment; worsening signal change: poor prognostic sign

monitoring.frequency: q6h while on IV steroids; daily on oral taper
monitoring.action: Sliding scale insulin; endocrine consult if persistent hyperglycemia

monitoring.frequency: q shift inpatient; daily if wearing cervical collar
monitoring.action: Pressure relief; collar padding; wound care; specialty mattress if immobile

disposition.criteria: Mild myelopathy (mJOA ≥15); stable exam; ambulatory without significant fall risk; independent bladder function (PVR <200 mL); adequate pain control on oral medications; MRI completed; surgical referral arranged if indicated; home environment safe; reliable follow-up within 1-2 weeks

Moderate-severe myelopathy (mJOA <15); progressive neurologic deficit requiring observation; inability to ambulate safely; neurogenic bladder requiring catheterization; IV steroids indicated; pending surgical evaluation; inadequate pain control; need for inpatient PT/OT assessment

High cervical cord compression (C3-C5) with respiratory compromise (FVC <20 mL/kg); post-operative monitoring after complex cervical spine surgery; hemodynamic instability; acute deterioration with rapidly progressive quadriparesis
Complex multi-level surgery; significant blood loss; airway concerns after anterior approach; hemodynamic instability; pre-existing pulmonary compromise
Need for spine surgery not available at current facility; need for MRI not available emergently; need for neurology/neurosurgery subspecialty input

Significant motor deficits preventing independent ADLs; gait impairment requiring assistive device training; neurogenic bladder/bowel requiring structured program; able to participate in 3 hours/day of therapy
Unable to tolerate 3 hours/day of intensive rehabilitation; requires skilled nursing care; ongoing wound care; cannot return home safely
